I've also toyed with the idea of time series prediction with NEAT.  I 
suspect that this topic may be of general interest and hope you'll 
continue discussion here.

Several questions:

Do you plan on using recurrent links as memory for the past period 
data leading up to the point where you want to make a forward 
prediction?  Ie. how do you plan to present the pattern on the 
inputs?  All at once for some back period, or only a time unit's 
(day's) worth at a time, and rely on some form of net memory?  One 
approach potentially suffers from dimensionality problems, and the 
other relies on a finding a good net activation/stableization(sp?) 
function.

How will you scale the input data, if at all?  Do you plan to 
normalize the data, so that the same trained net can possibly be used 
for more than one time series (different stock)?  If so, how would 
you normalize?

You mentioned that you'll use the stock data in your fitness 
function, and that you want the net to signal a "buy" or "sell".  For 
what time period into the future is a signal good?  And will you also 
have a "neutral" or no action (zero?) signal?

Do you plan on taking a pattern classifier/predictor approach, or a 
tournament approach, where different nets compete to see who "makes" 
the most, or does the best over time (similar to blondie24)?

I have dozens more questions, but this will do for starters!
Very Curious,
Karl



-- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "ej_1973" <e.j@v...> wrote:
> --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Kenneth Stanley" <kstanley@c...> 
wrote:
> > Sounds like an interesting project; I haven't heard of someone 
> doing 
> > stock predicition with NEAT before.  What kind of data are you 
> > thinking of using for input? 
> 
> To do the training I have written some perl scripts to site scrape 
> historical price data off yahoo finance. I now have a database of 
> 17,000 stocks from Europe and America, with historical end of day 
> data for each. Some (e.g. IBM) going back as far as 1962. Adding 
the 
> days of trading for all these stocks gives 29 million trading days, 
> with open,high,low,close and volume for each day. There should be 
> plenty there for training and testing.
> 
> As for how I'm going to use this data to provide inputs to a neural 
> net and use it to compose a fitness function for the GA....I have 
> some well developed ideas but I don't think this is the best place 
to 
> discuss them. If anyone wants to collaborate on the NEAT side of 
> things I'll happily divulge my ideas to you - drop me a direct mail.
> 
> If anyone wants to download the database (3 large binary files 
> containing the raw data) and the C++ classes to access it drop me a 
> line and we can sort out an ftp transfer. I can also share the 
> scripts I used to do the site scraping, although it would not be a 
> good idea if lots of people started using them - the yahoo finance 
> site would grind to a halt and they'd probably start making it 
harder 
> to do such things in future :-)
> 
> I'm currently trying to get my head around the NEAT C++ code so I 
may 
> well come back with some questions and observations in the near 
> future.
> 
> Regards,
> Emyr
